entry.title: Computer Network - The Web and HTTP

link.title: Computer Network - The Web and HTTP

entry.content:
1️⃣ Overview of HTTP

  • HyperText Transfer Protocol (HTTP): the Web’s application-layer protocol, a.k.a. the heart of the Web.
  • Web page: Document that consists of objects.
  • Object: a file - such as an HTML file, a JPEG image, a Javascript file, etc.
  • base HTML file: a HTML file that references the other objects in the page with objects’ URLs.
  • Web browsers: Client side of HTTP, in the context of the Web.
  • Web servers: Server side of HTTP, house Web objects, each addressable by a URL.
  • Stateless protocol: An HTTP server maintains no information about the clients

2️⃣ Non-Persistent and Persistent Connections

HTTP with Non-Persistent Connections

Each TCP connections is closed after the server sends the object - the connection does not persist for other objects.

  • Round-trip time (RTT): The time it takes for a small packet to travel from client to server and then back to the client.

HTTP with Persistent Connections

A brand-new connection must be established and maintained for each requested object. For each of these connections, TCP buffers must be allocated and TCP variables must be kept in both the client and server, which may be serving requests from hundreds of different clients simultaneously. Next, each object suffers a delivery delay of two RTTs - one RTT to establish the TCP connection and one RTT to request and receive an object.

3️⃣ HTTP Message Format

HTTP Request Message

A typical HTTP request message:

  • Request line: The first line of an HTTP request message.
  • Header lines: The lines after the first line of an HTTP request message.
    • Host: www.someschool.edu: Specifies the host on which the object resides.
    • Connection: close: The browser is telling the server that it doesn’t want to bother with persistent connections; it wants the server to close the connection after sending the requested object.
    • User-agent: Specifies the user agent that the browser type that is making the request to the server.
    • Accept-language: One of many content negotiation headers available in HTTP.
  • HTTP methods: GET, POST, HEAD, PUT, and DELETE

  • Entity body: Empty with the GET method, but is used with the POST method. An HTTP client often uses the POST method when the user fills out a form.

HTTP Response Message

A typical HTTP response message:

It has three sections: an initial status line, six header lines, and the entity body, containing the requested object itself.

  • Header lines
    • Connection: close: Tell the client that it is going to close the TCP connection after sending the message.
    • Date: Indicates the time and date when the HTTP response was created and sent by the server.
    • Server: Indicates that the message was generated by an Apache Web server.
    • User-agent: Header line in the HTTP request message.
    • Last-Modified: Indicates the time and date when the object was created or last modified.
    • Content-Length: Indicates the number of bytes in the object being sent.
    • Content-Type: Indicates that the object in the entity body is HTML text.
  • Status Code
    • 200 OK: Request succeeded and the information is returned in the response.
    • 301 Moved Permanently: Requested object has been permanently moved; the new URL is specified in Location. The client software will automatically retrieve the new URL.
    • 400 Bad Request: A generic error code indicating that the request could not be understood by the server.
    • 404 Not Found: The requested document does not exist on this server.
    • 505 HTTP Version Not Supported: The requested HTTP protocol version is not supported by the server.

4️⃣ User-Server Interaction: Cookies

Reference

  • Computer Networking 8th: A Top-Down Approach by James Kurose and Keith Ross
  • Computer Network Lecture by Seungsik Choi in Incheon National University

entry.title: Computer Network - Protocol Layers and Their Service Models

link.title: Computer Network - Protocol Layers and Their Service Models

entry.content:
1️⃣ Network Application Architectures

  • Application architecture: Designed by the application developer and dictates how the application is structured over the various end systems.
  • Client-server architecture: An always-on host, called the server, which services requests from many other hosts, called clients.
  • Data center: Housing a large number of hosts, is often used to create a powerful virtual server.
  • P2P architecture: the application exploits direct communication between paris of intermittently connected hosts, called peers.
  • Self-scalability: Although each peer generates workload by requesting files, each peer also adds service capacity to the system by distributing files to other peers.

2️⃣ Processes Communicating

  • Processes: A program that is running within an end system.

The Interface Between the Process and the Computer Network

  • Socket: A software between the application process and the transport-layer protocol.
  • Application Programming Interface (API): A socket is the interface between the application layer and the transport layer within a host.

Addressing Processes

  • IP address: An identification of a host.
  • Port number: Used to identify the host network application.

3️⃣ Transport Services Available to Applications

Reliable Data Transfer

  • Reliable data transfer: A protocol provides such a guaranteed data delivery service.
  • Loss-tolerant applications: A transport-layer protocol doesn’t provide reliable data transfer, some of the data sent by the sending process may never arrive at the receiving process.

Throughput

  • Bandwidth-sensitive applications: Applications that have throughput requirements.
  • Elastic applications: Makes use of as much, or as little, throughput as happens to be available.

Timing

A transport-layer protocol can also provide timing guarantees.

Security

A transport protocol can provide an application with one or more secuirty services.

4️⃣ Transport Services Provided by the Internet

TCP Services

TCP service model includes a connection-oriented service and a reliable data transfer service.

  • Connection-oriented service: TCP has the client and server exchange transport-layer control information with each other before the application-level messages begin to flow. This so-called handshaking procedure alerts the client and server, allowing them to prepare for an onslaught of packets. After the handshaking phase, a TCP connection is said to exist between the sockets of the two processes.
  • Reliable data transfer service: The communicating processes can rely on TCP to deliver all data sent without error and in the proper order. When on side of the application passes a stream of bytes into a socket, it can count on TCP to deliver the same stream of bytes to the receiving socket, with no missing or duplicate bytes.
  • Congesting-control mechanism: A service for the general welfare of the Internet rather than for the communicating processes. it throttles a sending process when the network is congested between sender and receiver.

UDP Services

UDP is no-frills, lightweight transport protocol, providing minimal services. It is connectionless, so there is no handshaking before the two processes start to communicate. It provides an unreliable data transfer service, meaning that when a process sends a message into a UDP socket, it provides no guarantee that the message will ever reach the receiving process. Also, messages that do arrives at the receiving process may arrive not in order. Lastly, UDP does not include a congestion-control mechanism,, so the sending side of UDP can pump data into the layer below at any rate.

Services Not Provided by Internet Transport Protocols

5️⃣ Application-Layer Protocols

Application-layer protocols Defines how an application’s processes, running on different end systems, pass messages to each other. In particular, it defines:

  • The types of messages exchanged, for example, request messages and response messages.
  • The syntax of the various message types, such as the fields in the message and how the fields are delineated.
  • The semantics of the fields, that is, the meaning of the information in the fields.
  • Rules for determining when and how a process sends messages and responds to messages.

Reference

  • Computer Networking 8th: A Top-Down Approach by James Kurose and Keith Ross
  • Computer Network Lecture by Seungsik Choi in Incheon National University

entry.content:
matplotlib package/library

The most used python library to visualize data such as 2d graph, image, and so on.

Import ‘pyplot’ module in ‘matplotlib’ library as ‘plt’

import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

Data Visualization

Input a list to the plot() function

import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

plt.plot([10, 20, 30, 40])
plt.show()

In this case, the y value is the value in the list and the x value increase by 1

Input two lists to the plot() function

import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

plt.plot([10, 20, 30, 40], [12, 43, 25, 15])
plt.show()

The two list are separated by ,

Add options to the graph

Add a title to the graph

import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

plt.title('plotting')

plt.plot([10, 20, 30, 40])
plt.show()

Tip ❗️

Add Malgun Gothic as font in order for title to support Korean

import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

plt.rc('font', family='Malgun Gothic')
plt.title('플로팅')

plt.plot([10, 20, 30, 40])
plt.show()

Add labels to the graph

import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

plt.title('plotting')

plt.plot([10, 20, 30, 40], label='legend1')
plt.plot([40, 30, 20, 10], label='legend2')

plt.legend()
plt.show()

Change location of the legend

import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

plt.title('plotting')

plt.plot([10, 20, 30, 40], label='legend1')
plt.plot([40, 30, 20, 10], label='legend2')

plt.legend(loc=1)
plt.show()

Change graph color

import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

plt.title('plotting')

plt.plot([10, 20, 30, 40], color='skyblue', label='legend1')
plt.plot([40, 30, 20, 10], color='pink', label='legend2')

plt.legend(loc=1)
plt.show()

Tip❗️

Find different colors to use as the graph color from:

https://matplotlib.org/stable/gallery/color/named_colors.html

Change the shape of line

import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

plt.title('plotting')

plt.plot([10, 20, 30, 40], color='skyblue', linestyle='--', label='legend1')
plt.plot([40, 30, 20, 10], color='pink', ls=':', label='legend2')

plt.legend(loc=1)
plt.show()

Tip❗️

Find different lines to use as the graph line from:

https://matplotlib.org/stable/gallery/lines_bars_and_markers/linestyles.html

Change shape of the marker

import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

plt.title('plotting')

plt.plot([10, 20, 30, 40], color='skyblue', linestyle='--', marker='v', label='legend1')
plt.plot([40, 30, 20, 10], color='pink', ls=':', marker='o', label='legend2')

plt.legend(loc=1)
plt.show()

https://matplotlib.org/stable/api/markers_api.html

entry.title: Computer Network - Networks Under Attack
entry.content:
The Bad Guys can put Malware into your Host via the Internet

  • Malware: Infectious data that comes with the actual requested data.
  • Botnet: What bad guys control and leverage for spam e-mail distribution or distributed denial-of-service attacks.
  • Self-replicating: Once it infects one host, fromm that host it seeks entry into other hosts over the Internet

The Bad Guys can Attack Servers and Network Infrastructure

  • Denial-of-service (DOS) attacks: Renders a network, host, or other piece of infrastructure unusable by legitimate users.
    • Vulnerability attack: Sends few well-crafted messages to vulnerable application or operating system running on targeted host. If the right sequence of packets is sent to vulnerable application or operating system, the service can stop or, worse, the host can crash.
    • Bandwidth flooding: The attacker sends a deluge of packets to the targeted host - so many packets that the target’s access link becomes clogged, preventing legitimate packets from reaching the server.
    • Connection flooding: The attacker establishes a large number of half-open or fully open TCP connections at the target host. The host can become so bogged down with these bogus connections that it stops accepting legitimate connections.

  • Distributed DoS (DDoS) attack: Attacker controls multiple sources and has each source blast traffic at the target.

The Bad Guys can Sniff Packets

  • Packet sniffer: A passive receiver that records a copy of every packet that flies by.

The Bad Guys can Masquerade as Someone You Trust

  • IP spoofing: Inject packets into the Internet with a false source address

Reference

  • Computer Networking 8th: A Top-Down Approach by James Kurose and Keith Ross
  • Computer Network Lecture by Seungsik Choi in Incheon National University

entry.title: Computer Network - Protocol Layers and Their Service Models

link.title: Computer Network - Protocol Layers and Their Service Models

entry.content:
1️⃣ Layered Architecture

Protocol Layering

  • Layer: Mixed implementation of hardware and software.
  • Services (a.k.a. service model): A specific task that is taken in a layer.
    • Performs a certain actions within that layer
  • An example of application-layer protocols are: HTTP and SMTP
    • These are implemented in software in the end systems; so are transport-layer protocols.

Tip ❗️

There are drawbacks of layering:

  • One layer may duplicate low-layer functionality.
  • Functionality at one layer may need information that is present only in another layer.

  • Protocol stack: The protocols of the various layers
  • The Internet protocol stack consists of five layers:
    • Physical Layer
    • Link Layer
    • Network Layer
    • Transport Layer
    • Application Layer

Application Layer

  • Message: Packet of information at the application layer.
  • Includes many protocols, such as the HTTP (Web document request and transfer), SMTP (transfer of e-mail messages), and FTP (Transfer of files between two end systems).
  • Domain Name System (DNS): Allows human-friendly names for Internet end systems in application layer.

Transport Layer

  • Segment: Transport-layer packet.
  • Transports application-layer messages between application endpoints.
  • There are two transport protocols
    • TCP
      • Provides a connection-oriented service to its applications.
      • Guaranteed delivery of application-layer message to the destination and flow control.
      • Breaks long messages into shorter segments and provides a congestion-control mechanism.
    • UDP
      • Provides a connectionless service to its applications.
      • No-frills service that provides no reliability, no flow control, and no congestion control.

Network Layer

  • Datagrams: Network-layer packet.
  • Provides the service of delivering the segment to the transport layer in the destination host
  • IP protocol: Defines the fields in the datagram as well as how the end systems and routers act on these fields.

Link Layer

  • Frames: Link-layer packet.
  • Depend on specific link-layer protocol that is employed over the link.
  • Examples of link-layer protocols
    • Ethernet protocol
    • WiFi protocol
    • Cable access network’s DOCSIS protocol

Physical Layer

  • Move entire frames from one network element to an adjacent network element.
  • Examples of transmission medium of link
    • Twisted-pair copper wire
    • Single-mode fiber optics

2️⃣ Encapsulation

entry.title: Computer Network - Delay, Loss, and Throughput in Packet-Switched Networks

link.title: Computer Network - Delay, Loss, and Throughput in Packet-Switched Networks

entry.content:
1️⃣ Overview of Delay in Packet-Switched Networks

The most important delays when packet travels are nodal processing delay, queueing delay, transmission delay, and propagation delay; As a whole, they accumulate and give a total nodal delay.

Types of Delay

Processing Delay

  • The time required to examine the packet’s header and determine where to direct the packet.
  • The time needed to check for bit-level errors in the packet.

Queuing Delay

  • Depends on the number of earlier-arriving packets that are queued and waiting for transmission on the link.

Transmission Delay

  • Amount of time required to push all of the packet’s bits into the link.
  • e.g. A 10 Mbps Ethernet link, the rate is R = 10 Mbps; for a 100 Mbps Ethernet link, the rate is R = 100 Mbps.

Propagation Delay

  • The time required to propagate from the beginning of the link to next router.
  • The bit propagates at the propagation speed of the link.
  • The range of propagation speed is:

-

  • e.g. propagation delay is the distance between two routers divided by the propagation speed.
    • The propagation delay is d/s, where d is the distance between the router A and router B and s is the propagation speed of the link.

Comparing Transmission and Propagation Delay

The difference between transmission delay and propagation delay is subtle but important.

Transmission Delay Propagation Delay
The amount of time required for the router to push out the packet The time it takes a bit to propagate from one router to the next
A function of the packet’s length and the transmission rate of the link A function of the distance between the two routers

2️⃣ Queuing Delay and Packet Loss

  • Queuing delay may vary from packet to packet.
    • e.g. if 10 packets arrive to an empty queue simultaneously, the first packet will not have any delay while the last packet suffer a relatively large queuing delay.
  • traffic intensity: La/R
    • L: number of bits that all packets consist of.
    • a: average rate at which packets arrive at the queue.
    • R: transmission rate(bits/sec) at which bits are pushed out of the queue.
    • If La/R > 1, then the average rate at which bits arrive the queue exceeds the rate at which the bits can be transmitted from the queue.
    • If La/R <= 1 and all packets arrive periodically, then every packet will arrive at an empty queue and there will be no queuing delay.
    • If La/R <= 1 and all packets arrive in burst, then the first packet will not have any queuing delay, while nth packet has (n-1)L/R seconds of delay.
    • For realistic case, the average queuing delay will depend on the La/R and can be shown with Figure 1.18.

Packet Loss

If a packet arrives to a router, that has reached its capacity limit, it will drop the packet and the packet will be lost.

3️⃣ End-to-End Delay

The total delay from a source to a destination can be calculated by equation below, assuming that there are N-1 routers between the source host and destination host.

Traceroute

  • Traceroute: A simple program that can run in any Internet host. It sends a special packets toward a destination, and as the packets work their way toward the destination, they pass through a series of router. When a router receives one of these special packets, it sends back to the source a short message that contains the name and address of the router.

This is an example of the output of the Traceroute program, where the route was being traced from the source host gaia.cs.umass.edu to a host in the computer science department ate the University of Sorbonne is Paris.

4️⃣ Throughput in Computer Network

  • Instantaneous throughput: At any instant of time is the rate (in bits/sec) at which the destination host is receiving.
  • Average throughput: F/T bits/sec
    • F is the number of bits a file consists of.
    • T is the time it takes for the destination host to receive.

Reference

  • Computer Networking 8th: A Top-Down Approach by James Kurose and Keith Ross
  • Computer Network Lecture by Seungsik Choi in Incheon National University

entry.title: Big Data - Stream(1)
entry.content:
Characteristics of Stream Data

  • Infinite, Burst, and Non-stationary
    • The size of the entire data set is unknown
  • Only INSTANTLY accessible
  • Stream management is important when the input rate is controlled externally:
    • Google queries
    • Twitter or Facebook status updates

Applications

  • Mining query streams
    • Google wants to know what queries are more frequent today than yesterday
  • Mining lick streams
    • Yahoo wants know which of its pages are getting an unusual number of hits in the past hour
  • Mining social network news feeds
    • e.g. look for trending topics on Twitter or Facebook
  • Sensor Networks
    • Many sensors feeding into a central controller
  • IP packets monitored at a switch
    • Gather information for optimal routing
    • Detect denial-of-service(DOS) attacks

The Stream Model

  • Input elements enter at a rapid rate, at one or more input ports
    • We call elements of the stream tuples
  • The system cannot store the entire stream

General Stream Processing Model

Operations on Data Streams

  • A subset of input streams
    • Sampling data from a stream
      • Construct a random sample
    • Queries over sliding windows
      • Number of items of type x in the last k elements of the stream
    • Filtering a data stream
      • Select elements with property x from the stream
    • Counting distinct elements
      • Number of distinct elements in the last k elements of the stream
    • Estimating moments
      • Estimate avg./std. dev. of the last k elements
    • …

Start from sampling

  • Sample a fixed proportion of elements in the stream
  • Maintain a random sample of fixed size over a potentially infinite stream
    • At any “time” k we would like a random sample of s elements

Sampling from a Data Stream: Sampling a fixed proportion

Sampling a Fixed Proportion

  • Scenario: Search engine query stream
    • Stream of tuples: (user, query, time)
    • Answer questions such as: How often did a user run the same query in a single day
    • Have space to store 1/10 of query stream
  • Naive solution
    • Generate a random integer for each query
    • Store the query if the integer is 0, otherwise discard

Problem with Naive Approach

  • Question: What fraction of queries by an user are duplicates?
    • Suppose each user issues x queries once and d queries twice.
  • Solution: Keep 10% of the queries.
    • Sample will contain x/10 of the singleton queries and 2d/10 of the duplicate queries at least once.
    • But only d/100 pairs of duplicates
      • d/100 = 1/10 * 1/10 * d
    • Of d “duplicates” 18d/100 appear exactly once
      • 18d/100 = ((1/10 * 9/10) + (9/10 * 1/10)) * d
  • Sample-based answer is the following:

  • Problem: Error would occur from “Probability of selection”.
    • Possible solution: Sampling user, not query
      • Pick 1/10th of users and take all their searches in the sample
      • Use a hash function that hashes the user name or user id uniformly into 10 buckets
    • Generalized Solution: Use stream of tuples with keys
      • Key is a subset of each tuple’s component
      • Choice of key depends on application
      • To get a sample a/b fraction of the stream:
        • Hash each tuple’s key uniformly into b buckets
        • Pick the tuple if its hash value is at most a

Sampling from a Data Stream: Sampling a fixed-sized tuples

Maintaining a fixed-size sample

  • Suppose we need to maintain a random sample S of size exactly s tuples due to the main memory size constraint because the length of the stream is unknown.
  • Suppose at time n we have seen s items.
    • Goal: Each item is in the sample S with equal probability of s/n.

Illustration (s = 2)

  • Stream: a x c y z k c d e g
  • At n = 5, each of the first 5 tuples is included in the sample S with equal probability.
  • At n = 7, each of the first 7 tuples is included in the sample S with equal probability.
  • Impractical solution would be to store all the n tuples seen so far and out of them pick s at random.

Solution: Reservoir Sampling

Algorithm

  • Store all the first s elements of the stream to S.
  • Suppose we have seen n-1 elements, and now the n th element arrives (n > s).
    • With probability s/n, keep the n th element, then it replaces one of the s elements in the sample S, picked uniformly at random

Claim

  • This algorithm maintains a sample S with the desired property. After n elements, the sample contains each element seen so far with probability s/n.

Proof of Reservoir Sampling By Induction

  • Assume that after n elements, the sample contains each element seen so far with probability s/n.
  • We need to show that after seeing element n+1 the sample maintains the property. Sample contains each element seen so far with probability s/(n+1).

Base Case

  • After we see n=s elements that sample S has the desired property. Each out of n=s elements is in the sample with probability y s/s = 1

Inductive Hypothesis

  • After n elements, the sample S contains each element seen so far with probability s/n.

Inductive step

  • After the element arrives ate n+1, for elements already in S, probability that the algorithm keeps it in S is:

  • At time n, tuples in S were there with probability s/n
  • Time n -> n+1, tuple stayed in S with probability n/(n+1)
  • Therefore, probability tuple is in S at time n+1 is:

Queries over a (long) Sliding Window

  • A useful model of stream processing is that queries are about a window of length N, the N most recent elements received.

Sliding Windows

  • A useful model of stream processing is that queries are about a window of length N, the N most recent elements received.

Sliding Window: 1 Stream

  • Sliding window on a single stream:
    • N = 6

Example Problem: Counting Bits

Problem

  • Given a stream of 0s and 1s
  • Be prepared to answer queries of the form How many 1s are in the last k bits? where k <= N

Obvious Solution

  • Store the most recent N bits, and when a new bit comes in, discard the N+1st bit.

Real Problem

  • What if we cannot afford to store N bits?
    • e.g. we’re processing 1 billion streams and N = 1 billion.

Simple Solution

  • A simple solution that does not really solve our problem: Uniformity assumption.

  • Maintain 2 counters:
    • S: number of 1s from the beginning of the stream.
    • Z: number of 0s from the beginning of the stream.
  • How many 1s are in the last N bits?

However, what if the stream is non-uniform? What if the distribution changes over time?

DGIM Method

  • Does NOT assume uniformity
  • Store O(log2N) bits per stream
  • Gives approximate answer, never off by more than 50%

Beginning Idea: Exponential Windows

  • Summarize exponentially increasing regions of the stream, looking backward
  • Drop small regions if they begin ate the same point as a larger region:

Pros

  • Stores only O(log2N) bits. O(logN) counts of log2N bits each.
  • Easy update as more bits enter
  • Error in count no greater than the number of 1s the “unknown” area

Cons

  • As long as the 1s are fairly evenly distributed, the error is small due to the unknown region - no more than 50%
  • However, it could be that all the 1s are in the unknown area at the end
  • In that case, the error changes w.r.t. N

Fixup: DGIM Method

  • We do not have to count both 0s and 1s
  • Instead of summarizing fixed-length blocks, summarize blocks with specific number of 1s. In other words, let the block sizes (number of 1s) increase exponentially
  • When there are few 1s in the window, block sizes stay small, so errors are small.

DGIM: Timestamps

  • Each bit in the stream has a timestamp, starting 1, 2, …
  • Record timestamps modulo N (the window size), so we can represent any relevant timestamp in O(log2N) bits, and store N = 4 using 2 bits

DGIM: Buckets

  • A bucket in the DGIM method is a record consisting of:
    1. The timestamp of its end [O(logN) bits]
    2. The number of 1s between its beginning and end [O(log log N) bits]
  • Constraint on buckets:
    • The number of 1s MUST be a power of 2.
    • Either one or two buckets with the same power-of-2 number of 1s.
    • Does not overlap in timestamps.
    • Sorted by size. Earlier buckets are not smaller than later buckets.
    • Buckets disappear when their end-time is > N time units in the past

Example: Representing a Stream by Buckets

Three properties of buckets that are maintained:

  • Either one or two buckets with the same power-of-2 number of 1s.
  • Buckets do not overlap in timestamps
  • Buckets are sorted by size

Updating Buckets

  • When a new bit comes in, drop the last (oldest) bucket if its end-time is prior to N time units before the current time
  • 2 cases: Current bit is 0 or 1
  • If the current bit is 0, no other changes are needed
  • If the current bit is 1:
    1. Create a new bucket of size 1, for just this bit
      • End timestamp = current time
    2. If there are now three buckets of size 1, combine the oldest two into a bucket of size 2
    3. If there are now three buckets of size 2, combine the oldest two into a bucket of size 4
    4. so on…

Example: Bucketized Stream

Why is the error 50%?

  • Suppose the last bucket has size 2r
  • Then by assuming 2r-1 of its 1s are still within the window, we make an error of at most 2r-1
  • Since there is at least one bucket of each of the sizes less than 2r, the true sum is at least:

Thus, error ate most 50%

Further Reducing the Error

  • Instead of maintaining 1 or 2 of each size bucket, we allow either r-1 or r buckets (r > 2), except for the largest size buckets; we can have any number between 1 and r of those
  • Error is at most O(1/r)
  • By picking r appropriately, we can tradeoff between number of bits we store and the error

Can we use the same trick to answer queries How many 1’s in the last k? where k < N?

  • Find the earliest bucket B that at overlaps with k. Number of 1s is the *sum of sizes of more recent buckets and *1/2 size of B.

Reference

  • Mining of Massive Datasets by Jure Leskovec, Anand Rajaraman, Jeff Ullman
  • Introduction to Big Data Lecture by Daejin Choi in Incheon National University

entry.title: Computer Network - The Network Core
entry.content:
1️⃣ Packet Switching

  • Messages: Anything the application designer wants which are exchanged by end systems.
    • May contain data such as an e-mail message, a JPEG image, or an MP3 audio file.
  • Packets: A format which a long messages are broken down to.
  • Packet switches: A tool that packet travels.
    • There are two predominant types of packet switches: routers and link-layer switches
    • Packets are transmitted over each communication link at a rate equal to full transmission rate of link.
    • e.g. Source system or a packet switch is sending a packet of L bits over a link with transmission rate R bit/sec -> packet is transmitted at L/R seconds

Store-and-Forward Transmission

  • Store-and-forward transmission: The packet switch must receive the entire packet before it can begin to transmit the first bit of the packet onto the outbound link.
    • To explore in more detail, consider a simple network consisting of two end systems connected by a single router, as shown below. A router will typically have many incident links, since its job is to switch an incoming packet onto an ongoing link; in this simple example, the router has the rather simple task of transferring a packet from one (input) link to the only other attached link. In this example, the source has three packets, each consisting of L bits, to send to the destination. At the snapshot of the time shown below, the source has transmitted some of packet 1, and the front of packet 1 has already arrived at the router. Because the router employs store-and-forwarding, at this instant of time, the router cannot transmit the bits it has received; instead it must first buffer the packet’s bits. Only after the router has received all of the packet’s bits can it begin to transmit the packet onto the outbound link. To gain some insight into store-and-forward transmission, let’s now calculate the amount of time that elapses from when the source begins to send the packet until the destination has received the entire packet. The source begins to transmit at time 0; at time L/R seconds, the source has transmitted the entire packet, and the entire packet has been received and stored at the router. At time L/R seconds, since the router has just received and stored at the router. At time L/R seconds, since the router has just received the entire packet, it can begin to transmit the packet onto the outbound link towards the destination; at time 2L/R, the router has transmitted the entire packet, and the entire packet has been received by the destination. Thus, the total delay is 2L/R.

Let’s now consider the general case of sending one packet from source to destination over a path consisting of N links each of rate R (thus, there are N-1 routers between source and destination). Applying the same logic as above, we see that end-to-end delay is:

Queuing Delays and Packet Loss

  • Output buffer(a.k.a. output queue): Stores packets that the router is about to send into that link.
  • Queuing delays: Variable and depend on the level of congestion in the network.
  • Packet loss: The arriving packet or one of already-queued packets will be dropped since the buffer is already completely full.

Forwarding Tables and Routing Protocols

Forwarding table: Maps destination addresses to that router’s outbound links. Routing protocols: Used to automatically set the forwarding tables.

2️⃣ Circuit Switching

There are 2 fundamental approaches to moving data through a network of links and switches: circuit switching and packet switching.

Tip❗️

Circuit-switched network Packet-switched network
Resources needed along a path to provide communication between the end systems are reserved for commuication between the end systems Resources needed along a path to provide communication between the end systems are not reserved for commuication between the end systems

End-to-end connection: The network must first reserve one circuit on each of two links.

Multiplexing in Circuit-Switched Networks

A circuit in a link is implemented with either frequency-division multiplexing(FDM) or time-division multiplexing(TDM).

  • Frequency-division multiplexing(FDM): The frequency spectrum of a link is divided up among the connections established across the link.
  • Time-division multiplexing(TDM): Time is divided of fixed duration and each frame is divided into a fixed number of time slots.
  • bandwidth: The width of the frequency band.

  • silent period: A period of silent in circuit switching when network resources are allocated to the connection but are not used.

3️⃣ A Network of Networks

Network Structure 1

Interconnects all of the access ISPs with a single global transit ISP.

  • Customer: The access ISP
  • Provider: The global transit ISP

Network Structure 2

Two-tier hierarchy with global transit providers residing at the top tier and access ISPs at the bottom tier.

  • Regional ISP: The access ISPs in the region connect.
  • Tier-1 ISPs: Similar to (imaginary) global transit ISP.
    • e.g. Level 3 Communications, AT&T, Sprint, and NTT.

Tip ❗️

There is a customer-provider relationship at each level of the hierarchy. The tier-1 ISPs do not pay anyone as they are at the top of the hierarchy.

Network Structure 3

Multi-tier hierarchy, which is still only a crude approximation of today’s Internet.

  • Points of Presence(PoPs): A group of one or more routers in the provider’s network where customer ISPs can connect into the provider ISP.
  • Multi-home Connect two or more provider ISPs.
  • Peer: A pair of nearby ISPs at the same level of hierarchy, directly connecting their networks together so that all traffic between them passes over the direct connection to reduce the cost.
  • Internet ExchangePoint(IXP): A meeting point where multiple ISPs can peer together.

Network Structure 4

Ecosystem consisting of access ISPs, regional ISPs, tier-1 ISPs, PoPs, multi-homing, peering, and IXPs

Network Structure 5

Builds on top of Network Structure 4 by adding content-provider networks

Reference

  • Computer Networking 8th: A Top-Down Approach by James Kurose and Keith Ross
  • Computer Network Lecture by Seungsik Choi in Incheon National University
